thread.title: National gymnastics champion surprised at winning score
thread.title_full: National gymnastics champion surprised at winning score

author: Hanne Davis
title: National gymnastics champion surprised at winning score
text:
National gymnastics champion surprised at winning score HANNE DAVIS Last updated 10:07, October 6 2015 Gymsports NZ 
Christchurch gymnast Courtney McGregor won the all around international senior title at the 2015 New Zealand Gymnastics Championships 
Christchurch gymnast Courtney McGregor has made her first steps towards Olympic qualification after winning the national all around elite title in Auckland. 
McGregor, who was the first Kiwi woman to make a World Cup final, posted a huge total of 55.20, which sets her up nicely for the World Gymnastics Championships in Glasgow at the end of October. 
"It felt awesome to finally put out four good routines and get my best all round score," said McGregor who admitted she was surprised to score so highly. 
It's McGregor's first senior title and a timely confidence boost before she steps on the plane to Scotland in a week's time. 
"Knowing that I can do that, and I didn't just do it on one day, I stayed on everything for both days so that's good. 
"I just need to keep training hard and hopefully Worlds will go well." 
Out of the five apparatus, McGregor excels on vault, and was seen as a serious medal contender at the 2014 Commonwealth Games before she was forced to withdraw through injury . 
She's hoping for fonder memories in 2015, and will be joined in Britain by her Christchurch School of Gymnastics team mates, World Cup medallist Charlotte Sullivan and national silver medallist Mackenzie Slee. 
"It's definitely good going as a team, because we all train together and can help push each other and cheer for each other." 
The World Championships should hopefully allow her to qualify for the Olympic test event in April, where she'll hope to finish the complicated process of securing a spot at the Rio games next August. Ad Feedback 
"I try not to think about it too much and just focus on the job I have to do at the moment, but it's exciting." 
New Zealand qualify one girl for the test event provided they meet the scoring criteria and McGregor felt it was within her reach particularly now she has experience of big competitions. 
"It was awesome to get such high scores at nationals, and know that it's possible if I keep doing what I'm doing." 
There was also success for Canterbury in the other senior events with Maggie Takami winning the Rhythmic Gymnastics title. She held off a strong challenge from fellow Cantabrian Keziah Oliver to win with a score of 52.469 after her ball, club, ribbon and hoop routines. 
Madaline Davidson also took home the senior women's trampolining title ahead of Bronwyn Dibb and Bethany Long. - Stuff
